orientation.purpose: Explain what this training is, why CIP-007 CSIR exists, and how it maps directly to audit evidence.
orientation.gate: I understand the purpose of this training

topics.title: What is CIP-007?
topics.detail: A standard that safeguards system security management for BES Cyber Systems.

topics.title: What is CSIR?
topics.detail: Cyber Security Incident Response under CIP-007 sets expectations for detecting, declaring, escalating, and documenting incidents.

topics.title: Why auditors care
topics.detail: Auditors verify you can prove detection, declaration, and response steps happened within defined time frames.

topics.title: Audit mapping
topics.detail: Each phase in this module links to an artifact auditors routinely request.

points.title: BES Cyber Asset vs non-BES
points.detail: CSIR applies to Cyber Assets and associated PACS that can impact the BES, even when owned by vendors.

points.title: Impact ratings
points.detail: Low, Medium, High determine depth of monitoring and escalation timelines.

points.title: No-incident myth
points.detail: Even if you have never declared an incident, auditors expect rehearsed evidence paths and mock records.

scope.check: Knowledge Check: Which systems require CSIR evidence under CIP-007? Answer: BES Cyber Systems and supporting tools that could affect BES reliability, based on their impact rating.

plan.lead: This is the heart of the training—adapted from CIP-Audit-Ready Module 6 guidance.
plan.note: Detection must be followed by declaration, escalation, documentation, and recovery—each with time stamps.

steps.title: Define a Cyber Security Incident
steps.detail: Unauthorized access, malware outbreaks, control loss, or integrity/availability impacts trigger CSIR.
steps.audit: Auditors ask: show where you define CSIR triggers.

steps.title: Detection vs Declaration
steps.detail: Detection is spotting the signal; declaration is when the CSIR lead confirms the incident and logs the start time.
steps.audit: Expect to show time-stamped detection and declaration logs.

steps.title: Escalation timelines
steps.detail: Who must be notified within 15, 30, or 60 minutes depending on impact rating and affected systems.
steps.audit: Auditors compare timelines to procedures and call trees.

steps.title: Internal vs reportable
steps.detail: Not all events are reportable. Internal CSIR still requires containment, lessons learned, and evidence.
steps.audit: Be ready to show how you classified and why.

steps.title: Roles & responsibilities
steps.detail: CSIR Lead, Ops, SOC, Engineering, Compliance, and Leadership each own decisions and approvals.
steps.audit: Auditors check RACI alignment and decision logs.

steps.title: Required artifacts
steps.detail: SIEM alerts, operator screenshots, network captures, ticket IDs, and recovery steps stored with timestamps.
steps.audit: Provide example evidence packages from practice or production.

steps.title: Coordination with CIP-008
steps.detail: CIP-007 CSIR feeds CIP-008 reporting without duplicating the notification workflow.
steps.audit: Show how CSIR records hand off into CIP-008 forms when required.

shared: Never guess the cause—capture what you see and escalate.
Time-stamp every action and who approved it.
Use the documented call tree; avoid side channels.
Record what you did not touch to preserve evidence.

responsibilities: Report alarms, abnormal HMI behavior, or unauthorized remote sessions immediately.
Preserve screens and logs; do not reboot unless directed.
Verify maintenance windows before allowing changes.
expectations: Can explain when to page the CSIR Lead.
Knows where to log operator notes for audits.
Understands which devices are BES and why.
never: Guess root cause on the record.
Start patching or disabling services on your own.

responsibilities: Validate control impacts, isolate affected segments safely, and support recovery steps.
expectations: Show change records and baselines for any configuration touched during response.
never: Bypass change control in an incident unless the CSIR Lead approves and logs it.

responsibilities: Confirm detection signals, declare incidents with the CSIR Lead, and capture forensic artifacts.
expectations: Map alerts to CIP-007 requirements and document containment sequencing.
never: Sweep logs without preserving originals or chain of custody.

responsibilities: Validate evidence completeness, track required approvals, and prep audit-ready packages.
expectations: Align incident records with CIP-007 and CIP-008 reporting thresholds.
never: Reword incident facts—keep statements factual and bounded.

responsibilities: Decide on communications, external coordination, and operational risk acceptance.
expectations: Knows when to engage regulators or Reliability Coordinators based on impact.
never: Commit to causes or blame before CSIR team confirms evidence.

responsibilities: Observe, request clarifications respectfully, and avoid directing actions.
expectations: Understands where records live and how to validate completeness.
never: Interfere with the live response or ask for changes during the event.

rules: Answer only what is asked; keep responses concise.
It is okay to say 'I don't know' followed by how you will find out.
Use deferral language: 'That is owned by the CSIR Lead; I can coordinate follow-up.'

examples.prompt: Auditor asks: When did you declare the incident?
examples.bad: Uh, sometime around lunch when things got weird.
examples.good: Declaration was at 12:14 per ticket CSIR-2024-07 after SOC confirmed repeated failed logins.

examples.prompt: Auditor asks: Did you block the traffic?
examples.bad: I think so; we closed some ports.
examples.good: The CSIR Lead approved isolating the jump host at 13:02; firewall change CHG-7781 documents the block.
Compliance / GRC was paged at 12:20 per the call tree; see notification log entry with recipient and time stamp.

questions.prompt: An auditor asks how you distinguish detection from declaration.
options: Detection is the alert; declaration is the formal CSIR start with a time stamp.
Declaration only happens for CIP-008 events.

questions.prompt: During an interview, an operator is asked who can approve system reboots during CSIR.
options: Only the CSIR Lead or delegate documented in the call tree.

questions.prompt: Auditor asks for proof of escalation timelines.
options: Say timelines are informal but fast.
Provide ticket time stamps and call tree logs.

questions.prompt: A SOC analyst is asked to describe required artifacts after containment.
options: Alerts, approvals, captures, and recovery validation notes with times.

questions.prompt: Compliance is asked what to do if an answer is unknown.
options: Admit not knowing and commit to follow-up with owner.

questions.prompt: Which systems require CSIR evidence under CIP-007?
options: BES Cyber Systems and related tools that can affect BES reliability
Only systems that already had an incident
feedback: IT assets alone are not in scope.
Correct—scope is based on BES impact.
Incidents are not required for scope.

questions.prompt: What makes an event a Cyber Security Incident?
options: Evidence of unauthorized access or impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability
feedback: Physical damage alone is not required.

questions.prompt: Who declares the incident after detection?
options: First person who sees the alert

questions.prompt: What should Operators never do during CSIR?
options: Reboot or change configs without CSIR Lead approval
Ticket IDs, call tree logs, approvals with times

questions.prompt: How should you answer audit questions?
options: Answer only what is asked and cite records
To ensure reportable events flow to required notifications

questions.prompt: What is expected of SOC during CSIR?
options: Capture forensic evidence and validate detections

questions.prompt: How do you show readiness if no incident occurred?
options: Maintain mock drills, evidence templates, and checklists

questions.prompt: What if you do not know the answer in an audit?
options: Say you will confirm with the owner and follow up

questions.prompt: Who controls remote access changes during CSIR?
What should Compliance / GRC bring to the table?
options: Evidence package templates and audit questions to expect

scope.Control Center Operator: BES assets you touch are in scope even if they seem routine.
scope.OT / SCADA Engineer: Impact ratings guide how quickly you must act on alarms.
scope.IT Security / SOC: Clarifies that monitoring systems themselves may be in scope.
scope.Compliance / GRC: Use this to brief auditors on scope boundaries.
scope.Auditor / Observer (read-only): Know the scoping so questions stay precise.

plan.Control Center Operator: Focus on detection cues and who to page.
plan.OT / SCADA Engineer: See where isolation and recovery steps fit.
plan.IT Security / SOC: Own the detection quality and evidence capture.
plan.Compliance / GRC: Track artifacts to the audit questions listed.
plan.Incident Commander / Leadership: Make decisions on communications and risk acceptance with the CSIR Lead.

execution.Control Center Operator: Your quick escalation prevents evidence loss.
execution.OT / SCADA Engineer: You are expected to preserve and document control actions.
execution.IT Security / SOC: You coordinate detection, declaration, and containment.
execution.Compliance / GRC: You curate the evidence and approvals.
execution.Incident Commander / Leadership: You own decisions and boundaries for public statements.
execution.Auditor / Observer (read-only): You validate fidelity without directing response.

etiquette.Control Center Operator: Stick to what you observed and logged.
etiquette.IT Security / SOC: Answer with data sources and time stamps.
etiquette.Incident Commander / Leadership: Use approved deferral language for regulatory questions.
etiquette.Auditor / Observer (read-only): Ask clarifying questions without leading answers.

mock.Control Center Operator: Practice saying what you saw, not theories.
mock.OT / SCADA Engineer: Map responses to change records and diagrams.

quiz.Control Center Operator: Expect situational questions about alarms and remote access.
quiz.OT / SCADA Engineer: Expect recovery and containment order questions.
quiz.IT Security / SOC: Expect detection quality and escalation questions.
quiz.Incident Commander / Leadership: Expect decision and notification boundary questions.
quiz.Auditor / Observer (read-only): Expect scope and observation boundary questions.
